snippet: A deal being worked out in Albany would expand collection of DNA to include samples from all people convicted of misdemeanors, not just felons, a move prosecutors say would help them solve crimes.
abstract: New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo and state lawmakers put the finishing touches on a deal to establish a so-called all-crimes DNA database, which would be one of the most expansive DNA databases in the nation; the database, which has the support of all the state's district attorneys and sheriffs, as well as that of 400 police chiefs, would require people convicted of felonies and misdemeanors to provide samples of their DNA to the state.

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and THOMAS KAPLAN
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson contributed reporting from Dixie, Miss.; Ashley Parker from Kirkwood, Mo., and Marjorie Connelly from New York.

lead_paragraph: A deal being worked out in Albany would expand collection of DNA to include samples from all people convicted of misdemeanors, not just felons, a move prosecutors say would help them solve crimes.

headline.seo: DNA Database, Pensions and Redistricting Are Part of Talks on Major Albany Deal
headline.main: New York State Set to Add All Convict DNA to Its Database
headline.print_headline: Albany Nearing Deal to Put All Convict DNA in State Database
